utterances: Representative JESSE JACKSON, JR. (Democrat, Illinois): If the decision is based upon record, upon tenure of service, upon consistency in service and loyalty to Barack Obama, which he will need on day one in the United States Senate, I would hope the governor would give my record consideration.
They married in 1999.
And not long after, their lives began to change.
Finally, in true ""American Idol"" fashion, it was time for the audience to decide.
They punched one of two buttons, voting either for or against the motion that Arab women should have full equality with men.
A few minutes later, Tim Sebastian announced the results of this very unscientific poll.
There we have it.
For the motion, 85.8 percent.
(Soundbite of applause)
This was, of course, not a typical Arab audience.
They speak English, and many have lived abroad.
The Qatar Foundation, which runs the forum, does plan to launch an Arabic version soon, but some Muslims don't like the fact that these debates are taking place in any language.
They argue that Muslims should be united at a time when Islam is perceived to be under attack from the West.
Tim Sebastian disagrees with that sentiment.
Actually, one of the most important aspects is that it's OK to disagree.
There doesn't always have to be a winner or loser.
But even if you do win or lose, you can walk away; you can shake hands and walk away.
This debate did end amicably, but not everyone walked away.
A few lingered on an especially warm Arabian night, parrying and occasionally agreeing with the question of the day.
Unidentified Woman #1: ...not my body, not my beauty.
Unidentified Woman #2: But you see, Islam is inherently feminist, I believe, but...
Unidentified Woman #1: Exactly.
Unidentified Woman #2: ...the notion of modern femininity...
Unidentified Woman #1: But that's what I wish you had said.
Eric Weiner, NPR News, Doha.
We've all heard the old adage: Whenever the U.S.
economy so much as sneezes, the rest of the world catches a cold.
These latest round of problems may be much, much more.
Krishna Guha is chief U.S.
economics correspondent for the Financial Times.
He joins us from his office in Washington, D.C.
Krishna, thanks very much for being with us.
My great pleasure.
And we're reviewing some of the ways in which obviously the U.S.
economy has been having its problems.
How would you characterize the rest of world right now?
Well, the rest of the world looks better than the U.S., but certainly not immune to the problems coming out of the U.S.
and the financial markets.
Growth in Asia, in particular in the emerging Asia - China, India, and some of the other fast-growing economies there - is very rapid, looks quite robust.
In Europe, Europe is doing okay.
Britain seems to be in more trouble than continental Europe.
But everyone is really trying to figure out just how much of an impact the problems from the U.S.
will have in the other parts of the world.
2008 was supposed to be the year of what's called decoupling.
Wasn't in which the rest of the world wouldâ€¦
That's right.
Yeah.
Well, has - do recent events suggest that that hasn't happened quite yet or what?
I think it's a question of degree.
The world today is somewhat less reliant on the U.S.
than it was in times past.
You have new growth polls, the emerging markets I talk to you about.
Continental Europe looks in better shape than it's been for a number of years.
But at the end of the day, the U.S.
is the biggest economy in the world.
The U.S.
financial markets are at the heart of the global financial markets.
The U.S.
banks and other financial institutions are at the heart of the world financial system.
So people who argue that the U.S.
can go into recession and that has no effect on the rest of world are being far too optimistic.
We often get the impression that the rest of the world will follow the movement in the U.S.
market.
But this week, Monday was a holiday here in the United States so, of course, the rest of the world went first.
Should we read anything into that?
I think what it tells you is just how globally integrated the financial markets are these days.
It's less a question of saying that people in Europe are following what happens in Asia or people in Asia are following what happens in the U.S.
This is one global financial market.

There are trades around the clock in different time zones, and a lot of the big financial institutions and players are making investments in multiple different markets, shuffling money from different assets and different places.
So we're all in it together.
Of course, the chairman of the Fed, Ben Bernanke, stepped in with the cut in the interest rates which certainly seem to steady the markets in this country for the time being.
What about reaction in the rest of the world?
Well, the other global markets also responded very positively.
After all, they're hoping that the U.S.
won't have a deep recession because if it did, it would cut down their exports to America and possibly make financial conditions in general difficult for everybody.
If the U.S.
should fall into a recession, is the world economy set up in such a way now?
Does the rest of the world have to follow or is this something that can caught our eyes?
The rest of the world doesn't have to follow the U.S.
into recession.
That is providing the U.S.
doesn't go into a really deep and brutal recession.
Mm-hmm.
But the rest of the world won't get off scot-free either.
You would expect to see some slow down in growth in other parts of the world and you'll also, I think, start to see much more differentiation between the performance of other foreign economies.
There are some countries like China and India, where the fundamental economic growth story is so strong it will probably - mostly run through with only a small moderation in growth.
And what's the number one cost you would bring up if you were having a conversation with a voter like that?
Illinois Governor Rod Blagojevich is going to make that call.
Reverend Jackson, what do you think about your son's chances of being appointed to the Senate?
Well, I do not know.
I only know I have such a passion for him, and I'm impressed with his record.
And I have nothing more to say about it.
And I approve that message.
The Reverend Jesse Jackson is the founder of the Rainbow Push Coalition.
He joined us from Chicago.
Thank you.
Thank you.
Washington, D.C., is no stranger to the limelight and hardly immune to scandal.
But when TMZ.com, the online celebrity gossip site, announced today they were launching a new version focused on celebrities inside the Beltway, it left some people wondering why.
For a site that built its fan base with headlines and videos of Britney, Lindsay and Paris - that's the celebutant, not the city -you have to wonder what sort of gossip the Capitol could offer.
Karl Rove or Nancy Pelosi don't inspire quite the inside celebrity gossip, say, of an Anna Nicole Smith.
To figure this out, we have called on Anne Schroeder.
She's gossip columnist for Politico.com, and we want to ask her.
Anne Schroeder, she's with us from a studio at Politico.com here in Arlington, Virginia.
Nice to have you on the program today.
(Gossip Columnist, Politico.com, Author, Shenanigans Blog): Well, good afternoon.
Thanks for having me.
And are we really that interesting in Washington, D.C.? It's a long time since Wilbur Mills and Fanny Fox.
Well, you know, I think the problem about Washington, D.C.
is that it's a huge mystery to people, and any mystery is going to be interesting.
So in the short run, is yes.
I think that there will be a lot of interest there for TMZ.
TMZ, at the end of the day, is here - I think the cash is here for their ad sales.
The want is here for them.
You know, and in terms of being able to produce gossip, their standards are a little bit lower than, say, the Washington Post.
So they might be able to run with something a lot quicker.
So what does the TMZ.com move to D.C.
say about how we view politics?
It's not necessarily we're talking about policy here, by about personality.
Well, by all means, you know, having the celebrity politician or sort of the rock star politician, that road has been, you know, on its way to being paved since the 1960s.
And now with the influx of the presidential campaign, you have Hillary, you have Barack.
They sincerely are rock star politicians.

And in the day and age of having celebrities who are famous that do nothing - you know, there's like the Brody Jenners of the world, the Paris Hiltons of the world - these people sell magazines and they make news repeatedly.
And then there's the politician.
So it's not a far cry to say that there certainly is a celebrity aspect to it.
And at the end of the day, the politicians have a lot of power, and power is very influential.
And I think people are really curious about that.
They can sell magazines just as well as Brody Jenner.
Yeah, but for those of us who live inside the Beltway, it's a little hard to imagine why people outside the Beltway would care who a committee chairman is dating.
Well, I definitely think that needs to be proven.
You know, I was talking to the TMZ folks the other day, and their publicist said well, big celebrities are everywhere, even outside of Hollywood.
Well, that's fair enough, but then I was talking to some Senate people and some House staffers on the Hill.
A lot of their reactions first were what is TMZ?
(Soundbite of laughter)
